Full Description: Havelock is a work management and collaboration platform that keeps all important information updated in real-time and stored in one place. Havelock offers the simplest way for multi-department companies to manage many projects effectively from one place and have quick access to all project information updated in real-time. Culture of Action - Plan dynamically and stop re-arranging your target deadlines to match reality - Plan and schedule only actionable milestones - Put all actionable milestones in a single “Action hub” - Assign only actionable tasks - Organize all communication around tasks to make it easily traceable Actionable dependencies Before you continue reading, let’s explain what we mean by “actionable”, because it is a word that you would hear a lot. When a milestone or a task is actionable, it means you can start to work on it immediately without worrying that you have to wait for someone else to finish their work. Also, it means that all necessary files and documents to execute the task are at your disposal. The purpose of Actionable Dependencies is simple – to inform PMs when milestones become actionable (workable) or in other words, it’s time for action. Dependencies are set automatically when all preceding milestones are executed. Most of our competitors use dependencies to automatically reschedule tasks or milestones but we believe that automatic rescheduling of initial plans is a wrong practice. We keep the initial plans unchanged for a reason – to compare them with the real situation. Comparison is the best way for a company to learn, improve and build sustainable know-how. Dynamic Reminders Actionable Dependencies and Dynamic Reminders are at the very core of our patentpending methodology. Dynamic Reminders are very important. Imagine a project manager (PM) has to, well, manage 100 projects with 30 milestones each, and a number of tasks related to each milestone and assigned to different teams. Of course, we expect the PM to react to every single change and keep all projects updated with a 100% match with the real situation. In other words, the PM must monitor nearly 3,000 milestones every day and have instant information about all emerging deviations so that he can update all unrealistic target deadlines with achievable ones. Monitoring 3,000 milestones every day!? Is it possible and what happens in reality? When an actionable dependency is activated, the system automatically adds a dynamic reminder to the milestone in question. The dynamic reminder serves as a guarantee that the PM will be immediately informed when an action is needed. When a milestone is executed the system automatically informs the PM which other milestones have just become actionable. As a result, the PM doesn’t have to monitor 3,000 milestones because they manage only actionable ones – or less than 5% based on our experience. Projects become transparent and informative as never before. We can see the initial plans (hopes), the execution dates (reality), the delays (comparison between the two), and the next actionable steps. Do we need more? The Dynamic Reminders Hub collects the dynamic reminders for all projects, prioritised by the date of the required action (for “Today”, “Tomorrow”, and so on). This is the very first moment tasks appear in our concept. It is wrong to create and assign tasks before it is possible to start to work on them – it only adds noise to the system. “Non-actionable” tasks in the daily “to-do” lists of employees create not only a stressful environment but also ruin the credibility of such lists. On the other hand, the logical consequence of dealing with actionable milestones is that all created tasks are also actionable. This is a huge game-changer. Only a month after kickoff, our client reported 100% actionable tasks registered in the system – there were no tasks “on hold” or “waiting for something to happen”. What’s more, communication noise was reduced by three-four times. Task-related communication & escalation All communication in Havelock happens only on the task-level – each task has its own communication channel – which facilitates the search for information. Additionally, each project, milestone, and task have a library with related files. This way, all communication history is preserved, it’s easily searchable and increases the system’s transparency. If a task assignee has questions or needs clarification, they can send a direct message to the person in concern. Description: Viblast is an innovator operating in the online video industry that improves on last-mile delivery, stream quality and playback.
Headquarters Regions: European Union (EU), Europe, Middle East, and Africa (EMEA)
Full Description: Viblast is an innovator operating in the online video industry that improves on last-mile delivery, stream quality and playback. The company’s software technology steps on WebRTC and HTML5 and solves complex problems such as client-assisted delivery and HLS & DASH playback in HTML5 without the use of plugins. Its flagship product Viblast PDN (short from peer-assisted delivery network) is the winner of Best Innovation 2014 at WebRTC Global Summit 2014. It optimizes video delivery to large numbers of simultaneous viewers through patent-pending peer-assisted technology. It scales real-time, improves QoE parameters and relieves last-mile video traffic congestion while reducing reliance on costly streaming infrastructure.  Targeted at broadcasters and content providers, Viblast PDN enables the delivery of live and on-demand high-definition video to any device and platform in a massively scalable and cost-effective way, achieving bandwidth savings of up to 70%. The technology seamlessly complements existing delivery solutions (CDN/in-house deployments).  Viblast Player is the company’s solution to the challenge of HLS & MPEG-DASH playback in HTML5 plugin-free. It is one of very few available technologies able to play adaptive bitrate (ABR) streams without Flash in HTML5. Besides ABR playback of live and on-demand content, it handles encrypted HLS and DRM-protected DASH streams. Viblast is especially well-timed with the introduction of 4K, which will generate substantial traffic when adopted on a mass scale.

Our aim is to turn our solution into a ubiquitous product that provides only subtle feedback in real time and displays detailed information only when explicitly desired by the user.
